title-group.article-title: Ophthalmoplegic Migraine With Persistent Dilated Pupil

abstract.p: Ophthalmoplegic migraine is a rare disorder characterized by childhood-onset ophthalmoplegia and migraine headaches. The third cranial nerve is commonly involved, while involvement of the sixth and fourth cranial nerves is uncommon. We present the case study of a 15-year-old female teenager whose condition was diagnosed with ophthalmoplegic migraine when she was 9 years old and since then has experienced multiple and recurrent attacks. Since the diagnosis, she has exhibited a persistent right-eye mydriasis, despite resolution of migrainous episodes. Pupillary involvement in ophthalmoplegic migraine is the rule in children, with total recovery in the majority of cases. We will discuss some aspects related to the eventual association between this entity and other comorbidities, such as Adie tonic pupil, emphasizing the fact that the underlying mechanisms of this residual mydriasis are not fully understood.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Ophthalmoplegic migraine, a rare form of migraine, is characterized by childhood-onset ophthalmoplegia, accompanied by migraine headaches. 1 It is commonly associated with third cranial nerve palsy, but sometimes there is also involvement of the sixth and fourth nerves. 2
–9

The first description of this entity was made by Charcot et al at the end of the 19th century (1890). In the revised edition of the International Classification of Headache disorders (ICHD-II, 2004), it is considered a migraine variant. 1 The diagnosis requires the following criteria: at least 2 episodes of migraine like headaches either accompanied or followed by paresis of the third, fourth, or sixth cranial nerves within 4 days of the onset. 8

With respect to its etiology, though not clear, it is considered by some authors as being a recurrent inflammatory demyelinating illness of idiopathic or postviral origin. 2 It is an exclusion diagnosis and therefore studies should be performed, namely, to exclude any demonstrable intracranial lesion. 9 Noninvasive imaging tests, such as magnetic resonance angiography or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), are the criterion standard and should be performed in all patients. 3

With an incidence estimated in 0.7 cases per 1 million inhabitants per year, there is no gender difference and it may also affect young children. Pupillary involvement with mydriasis is usually the rule, and generally supports a clinical diagnosis of ophthalmoplegic migraine. 1,2
The therapeutic approach involves corticosteroid therapy, usually methylprednisolone or prednisolone, initially pulses, followed by oral therapy for about 1 week with gradual tapering in 6 weeks. 1

Concerning the prognosis and evolution of this disorder, total recovery in each episode is the rule. 2 However, permanent deficits have been associated in some cases with multiple and recurrent episodes. 2

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: We report the case study of a girl, who presented, at age 9 years, with double vision, right-eye deviation and ptosis, complaining of nausea, dizziness, and vomiting for 2 days. A family history of migraine headaches was reported and she had been complaining of headaches for the last 8 months.

On physical examination there was a ptosis in the right eye, with a dilated pupil, and no reflex to light or accommodation. The remaining neurologic examination was unremarkable, including examination of the fundus, which did not reveal any signs of papilledema.

A cerebral computed tomographic scan was performed, with no abnormalities. At this time, the patient was referred to a neurology consultation and posterior MRI and a magnetic resonance angiography were performed, also showing no abnormalities. Because of technical limitations, the magnetic resonance exams were not performed during the episodes of migraine.

Since the inaugural episode when she was diagnosed with ophthalmoplegic migraine, the patient has had several episodes, similar in presentation and duration of symptoms, with a 2- to 3-month interval.

The patient is usually treated with a 3-day oral corticosteroid therapy, with good clinical response. However, despite the resolution of migraine attacks, she has a persistent dilated right pupil, which remains, at age 15 years, with no precise explanation. It is important to emphasize that an analysis of previously taken photographs did not show anisocoria.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In children, pupillary involvement in ophthalmoplegic migraine is the rule. There is a total recovery in most cases, with resolution of the symptoms in about 10 days. 1

There are some descriptions of migraine patients with a transient unilateral mydriasis during the attack or within a short time after it. 5 However, mydriasis that outlasts the duration of the migrainous episode is not frequent, and it has been regarded as a possible comorbidity between migraine and Adie tonic pupil. 5,8

Adie pupil is a transitory, unilateral mydriasis, unresponsive to light stimulation, with light-near dissociation, in the absence of an extraocular motility abnormality. The diagnostic test (topical intraocular treatment of diluted 0.125% pilocarpine) indicates a postganglionic parasympathetic lesion, with a stronger response induced in the affected eye. 8

The reliability of this test has been questioned, with regards to the distinction between Adie tonic pupil (postganglionic lesion) from a preganglionic third nerve lesion, as seen in ophthalmoplegic migraine. 8 On the other hand, both diagnoses are mutually exclusive, as in ophthalmoplegic migraine there must be an ocular movement disorder, which by definition excludes Adie tonic pupil.

This phenomenon has already been described in at least 3 patients: 1 patient presented transient Adie pupil associated with migraine with aura 9 ; another patient had a permanent deficit of the third cranial nerve after an episode of ophthalmoplegic migraine 10 ; and a third presented right-eye mydriasis lasting for 2 years from the episode of ophthalmoplegic migraine. 8

In our patient, with the diagnosis of ophthalmoplegic migraine according to the diagnostic criteria, we have no explanations for the long-lasting right-eye mydriasis. A diagnosis of Adie tonic pupil is excluded, because the patient had oculomotor deficits.

To our knowledge, the etiology and mechanisms behind an isolated, permanent mydriasis after ophthalmoplegic migraine episodes remains unexplained, and further studies are needed to help understand the underlying mechanisms of this possible correlation.
